fields.question: Which one of the following is more probable regarding the Harappa Script?
fields.explanation: It was written in the Boustrophedon style. It is written in the first line from right to left and in the second line from left to right. It was pictographic in nature. 400 to 500 sign or logo symbolic used in this script. It is still an undecipherable script.

fields.question: The great Bath was found in
fields.explanation: The Great Bath was found in Mohenjo-Daro. A bronze dancing girl found in Mohenjodaro. Granary was the largest building of Mohenjo Daro.

fields.question: Which emperor has been called Napoleon of India?
fields.explanation: Samudragupta was the greatest ruler of the Gupta dynasty. He was called Napoleon of India by V. A. Smith. He was a follower of Vaishnavism but tolerant of other religions.

fields.question: The first metal discovered by man was
fields.explanation: Copper is the first metal discovered by humans. The first domesticated animal was the dog. The Indus civilized people did not know the use of iron. It was contemporary with the Chalcolithic era.

fields.question: Who composed the Allahabad Prasasti?
fields.explanation: Harisena was a court poet of Samudra Gupta.

fields.question: Which was a major port of the Indus Valley?
fields.explanation: Lothal was part of the present state of Gujarat. It was a seaport located on the banks of the river Bhogabar. In 1954 S.R. Rao has discovered it.

fields.question: What was the policy of Samudragupta in the south?
fields.explanation: This policy of Samudragupta is described as Digvijaya or defeating the enemy kings of the South, Grahana or getting the authority over the kingdoms and then Anugraha allowing them to rule their Kingdoms under his Suzerainty. In course of his Southern Campaign, he humbled as many as twelve princes.

fields.question: Who was the first independent King of Bengal?
fields.explanation: Sasanka was a king of the Gauda Kingdom and capital was Karnasubarna, in present-day Murshidabad in West Bengal.

fields.question: The Indus Valley Civilization belongs to the
fields.explanation: Indus Valley civilization is also known as Harappan civilization. It belongs to the Chalcolithic period and Bronze age. They were not aware of iron metal. There is no clear timeline for the Indus valley civilization. It is considered that they were active from 2900 BC to 1700 BC.

fields.question: Who wrote Ramcharita?
fields.explanation: Ramcharit was written in Sanskrit by Sandhyakar Nandi. He was a contemporary poet of the Pala kingdom of Bengal. A palm leaf manuscript of Ramcharitam, discovered by Hariprasad Shastri, a Bengali scholar, is preserved in the museum of the Calcutta Asiatic Society. Ramcharitmanas was written by Goswami Tulsidas in the Awadhi language.

fields.question: Total number of Puranas
fields.explanation: There is a total of 18 Puranas. It contains many things all together like mythology, cosmology, various legends, folk belief, codes of law, miscellaneous topics. It has suggested a change in the mode of the warship from sacrifice to idol worship. It contains a description of an ancient legend that was heavily colored with superstitions. The Puranas are Brahma Puran, Vishnu Purana, Shiva Purana, Padma Purana, etc. The oldest purana is Matsya Purana.

fields.question: Sulapani was a famous artist of the
fields.explanation: Sulapani was one of the finest artists of the Sena era. Other important people are Sandhyakar Nandi, Madhavkar, Jayadeva, Umapati, Dhoyi, etc.

fields.question: Divya was the leader of the
fields.explanation: The Varendra rebellion (also known as the Kaivarta revolt), a revolt against King Mahipala II. The revolt was led by Divya. The Kaivarta (community) were able to capture Varendra by this rebellion. Later on, in 1082 CE, King Rampala was succeeded to recapture his fatherland Varendra by defeating Vim with the assistance of neighboring vassals. Rampala is said to be the founder of the Third Pala Empire. Sandhyakar Nandi, the author of Ramcharit, was his court poet.

fields.question: With the people of which country Harappan people carried trade?
fields.explanation: Indus people used to trade with the Sumerians, Mesopotamians (now southern Iraq) on waterways and land routes. The Harappan region was known as Meluha in Sumer. There was clear evidence of trading between these two civilizations. The same seals were found in both regions.

fields.question: Who was the court poet of Samudra Gupta?
fields.explanation: Harisena was a 4th-century Sanskrit poet, an important figure in the court of the Gupta emperor, Samudragupta. His most famous poem, written in 345 C.E., describes the bravery of Samudragupta and is inscribed on the Allahabad Pillar.

fields.question: Which of the following is a Harappan site located in Rajasthan?
fields.explanation: Kalibangan discovered by B. K. Thapar. It was situated on the banks of the river Ghaghara.

fields.question: Name the last Tirthankara
fields.explanation: According to the Jains, a Tirthankara is a person who has conquered the cycle of death and rebirth by himself and paved the way for others to follow. There were 24 Tirthankars. The first Tirthankar was Rishabhanatha. The symbol used for him is the Bull. The 23rd Tirthankara was Parshvanath and the symbol used for him was Snake. The twenty-fourth Tirthankara was Mahavira and the symbol used for him was Lion. He was the original founder of Jainism.

fields.question: Rice cultivation is associated with the Harappan site of
fields.explanation: Lothal was the first dockyard in the world. It was called the entrance of Harappan civilization was located at present-day Gujarat. Lothal was discovered by S.R. Rao in 1954. Evidence of rice found in Lothal and Rangpur both are located in Gujarat.

fields.question: Taxila was the famous site of
fields.explanation: Taxila was an important city of Ancient India on the eastern shore of the Indus river. Its origins go back to c. 1000 BCE. Taxila meaning City of Cut Stone or Takṣa Rock in Sanskrit is a significant archaeological site located in Punjab, Pakistan.

fields.question: Sabha and Samiti are two democratic institutions of
fields.explanation: In the era of the Vedic age, there are many assemblies like Sabha, Samiti, Vidhata, and Gana as mentioned in Rig Veda. Among these Sabha and Samiti were the two most important assemblies. The status of women was admirable they are allowed to participate in Sabha and Samiti. Even the King and the Chief showed eagerness to win the support of Sabha and Samiti. The important administrative division in the Vedic age is: Jana: Aryan tribes were known as Jana, but there was no mention of Janapada. Vis: Jana was divided into a group of villages called vis and headed by Vrajapati. Grama: Vis again divided into grama and headed by Gramins. Kulas: Grama further divided in Kulas i.e family and headed by Kulapa.

fields.question: Who composed 'Ai-hole' prasasti?
fields.explanation: Aihole was located in the state of Karnataka and was the first capital of the Chalukyas. Many inscriptions have been found here but the inscription at the Meguti temple is popularly known as the Aihole Inscription. It contains many historical events of Chalukyas. It was written in Sanskrit and it uses the old Kannada script. There are also references to the defeat of Harshavardhana by Pulakesin II and the victory of the Chalukyas on Pallavas. There is a reference to the transfer of capital from Aihole to Badami by Pulakesin I. The Aihole inscription was written by Ravikirti, a court poet of the Chalukya king Pulakesin II. Pulakesin II ruled from 610 to 642 CE.

fields.question: Indus-valley civilization is called
fields.explanation: The most striking feature of the Indus Valley Civilization was its town planning. It was an urban civilization, whereas the Vedic period was rural in nature. Great Bath was found in both Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro. Granary was the largest building of the Indus Valley civilization found in Mohenjo-Daro.

fields.question: Where was the capital of Sasanka?
fields.explanation: Shashanka was the first independent king of a unified polity in the Bengal region, called the Gauda Kingdom. He reigned between 600 CE and 636/7 CE, whereas other sources place his reign between 590 and 625 CE. He is the contemporary of Harsha and of Bhaskaravarman of Kamarupa. His capital was at Karnasubarna, in present-day Murshidabad in West Bengal. The development of the Bengali calendar is often attributed to Shashanka because the starting date falls within his reign.

fields.question: The Upanishads were compiled around
fields.explanation: The Upanishads consist of a collection of religious and philosophical texts. They were written probably between 800 BCE and 500 BCE. It was the time when the traditional Vedic religion was being questioned by Indian society.

fields.question: The Origins of Indian Music may be traced to one of the following Vedas
fields.explanation: The Vedic age was considered to be around 1500 BC to 600 BC in India. Earlier Sama Veda was known as Saman. It contains 1,875 verses that are primarily taken from the Rig Veda. An earlier trace of Indian music is found in Sama Veda.

fields.question: The famous physician during Buddha's time was
fields.explanation: Sushruta was known as the “Father of Indian Medicine” and the “Father of Plastic Surgery”. Jivika was a personal physician of Haryanka king Bimbisara and Buddha.

fields.question: In which ancient text do you find the earliest reference to the Varna System?
fields.explanation: Purusha Sukta, 10th mandala of the Vedas, mentions the four varnas by name, although the word 'varṇa' itself is not mentioned. The 1st and 10th mandalas were compiled in the later Vedic period.

fields.question: How many Tirthankaras were there in ancient India?
fields.explanation: According to the Jains, a Tirthankara is a person who has conquered the cycle of death and rebirth by himself and paved the way for others to follow. There were 24 Tirthankars. The first Tirthankar was Rishabhanatha, symbolized by the Bull. The 23rd Tirthankara was Parshvanath, symbolized by the Snake. The twenty-fourth Tirthankara was Mahavira, symbolized by the Lion. He was the original founder of Jainism.

fields.question: Which metal was unknown to the Indus people?
fields.explanation: Indus Valley civilization is also known as Harappan civilization. It belongs to the Chalcolithic period and Bronze age. They were not aware of iron metal. There is no clear timeline for the Indus valley civilization. It is considered that they were active from 2900 BC to 1700 BC.

fields.question: According to Buddhism, the cause of all sorrows is
fields.explanation: The four noble truths by Buddha (Arya Satyas) are: Dukkha (suffering, incapable of satisfying, painful) is an innate characteristic of existence in the realm of samsara. Samudaya (origin, arising) of this dukkha, which arises or 'comes together' with taṇhā ('craving, desire or attachment'). Nirodha (cessation, ending) of this dukkha can be attained by the renouncement or letting go of this taṇhā. Magga (path, Noble Eightfold Path) is the path leading to renouncement of tanha and cessation of dukkha. These are traditionally identified as the first teachings given by the Buddha and are considered some of the most important teachings in Buddhism.

fields.question: Which of the following Gods do not belong to the Rigvedic period?
fields.explanation: Gods mentioned in Rig Vedas are Indra, Agni, Varuna, Soma, Savitri, Vishnu, Aditi, Apsaras, Rudra, Usha, Prithvi, and many more. But there was no mention of God Shiva. Indra was known as Purandhara (i.e., Breaker of Fort). 250 Rig Vedic hymns are dedicated to Indra. He was the most important divinity, and Agni was second in the list.

fields.question: The oldest Veda is
fields.explanation: Rig Vedas is the oldest religious text in the world. It contains 1,208 hymns and 10,600 verses, consisting of 10 mandalas.

fields.question: The oldest school of Indian Philosophy is
fields.explanation: Indian philosophy refers to philosophical traditions which developed in the Indian subcontinent. A traditional classification divides orthodox (āstika) and heterodox (nāstika) schools of philosophy, depending on one of three alternate criteria: whether it believes the Vedas as a valid source of knowledge; whether the school believes in the premises of Brahman and Atman; and whether the school believes in afterlife and devas. From this Hindu point of view, there are six major schools of orthodox (āstika) Indian Hindu philosophy: Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Samkhya, Yoga, Mīmāṃsā, and Vedanta, and five major heterodox (nāstika) schools: Jain, Buddhist, Ajivika, Ajñana, and Charvaka. However, there are other methods of classification; Vidyaranya, for instance, identifies sixteen schools of Indian philosophy by including those that belong to the Śaiva and Raseśvara traditions.

fields.question: Whom does the Gayatri Mantra in the Rig Veda address?
fields.explanation: The famous Gayatri mantra is addressed to Savitri. The Gayatri mantra was mentioned in the third mandala of the Rig Veda. It was composed by the sage Viswamitra to offer prayer to the solar deity Savitri. Savitṛ is a Vedic Sun deity. The maximum number of hymns was dedicated to Indra.

fields.question: Buddha was born in
fields.explanation: According to Buddhist tradition, Gautama Buddha lived between 563 BCE to 483 BCE. He was born into an aristocratic family in the Shakya clan. He was born in Lumbini near Kapilavastu, Nepal. Extra Info: Parents: Śuddhodana (father) and Maya Devi (mother), Spouse: Yasodharā, Children: Rāhula, Other names: Shakyamuni ('Sage of the Shakyas'), Masters (Gurus): Alara Kalama and Uddaka Rāmaputta, Died (Mahaparinirvana): c. 483 BCE (aged 80) in Kushinagar, Malla Republic (according to Buddhist tradition).

fields.question: During which period was the Vedic Literature composed?
fields.explanation: The Vedic Literature, comprising the four Vedas (Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvaveda) along with their respective Samhitas, Aranyakas, Brahmanas, and Upanishads, was composed during the period from 1500 B.C. to 1000 B.C. The later Vedic age, which spans from 1000 B.C. to 600 B.C., continued to build on these texts, further developing the spiritual and philosophical concepts contained within them.

fields.question: Who discovered the Indus Valley civilization?
fields.explanation: The Indus Valley Civilization was discovered by Rakhaldas Banerjee, along with other notable archaeologists like John Marshall, Rai Bahadur Daya Ram Sahni, and Madho Sarup Vats. Excavations began in 1921, revealing the remains of an ancient civilization in Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro, which significantly advanced our understanding of early human history.

fields.question: Buddhist religious scripture Tripitaka was written in
fields.explanation: The Tripitaka, also known as the Pali Canon, is the traditional term for Buddhist scriptures. It was written in the Pali language and consists of three main 'baskets' (Pitakas): the Vinaya Pitaka (discipline), the Sutta Pitaka (discourses), and the Abhidhamma Pitaka (higher teachings).

fields.question: The first permanent home of the Aryans in India was
fields.explanation: The Aryans initially settled in the region known as the Sapta Sindhu, which includes the area of present-day Punjab. This area was known for its fertile lands and conducive environment for settlement and agriculture, making it the first permanent home of the Aryans in India.

fields.question: The word Aryan denotes
fields.explanation: The term 'Aryan' originally referred to the Indo-European speaking peoples who migrated into the Indian subcontinent. While it has often been associated with a race, modern scholarship tends to view 'Aryan' more as a linguistic group. The Aryans considered themselves a noble class and settled in the Indo-Gangetic plains.

fields.question: Buddhist doctrines are contained in
fields.explanation: The Dhammapada is a collection of sayings of the Buddha in verse form and is one of the most widely read and best-known Buddhist scriptures. It contains essential teachings and doctrines of Buddhism, presented in a way that is accessible to laypeople.

fields.question: Where did Buddha preach his first sermons?
fields.explanation: Buddha preached his first sermon, known as the 'Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta' or 'Setting in Motion the Wheel of Dharma', at Saranath. This event marks the beginning of his teaching career and the establishment of the Buddhist Sangha.

fields.question: Which ruler was contemporary of both Buddha and Mahavira?
fields.explanation: Ajatasatru was a ruler of the Haryanka dynasty of Magadha and was a contemporary of both Mahavira and Gautama Buddha. His reign is noted for significant interactions with both Jainism and Buddhism.

fields.question: Jivaka mentioned in the early Buddhist literature was a
fields.explanation: Jivaka was a renowned physician during the time of the Buddha. He served as the personal physician to Buddha and was well-respected for his medical expertise.

fields.question: Which of the following was not a part of Tripitaka's three baskets?
fields.explanation: The Tripitaka, or Pali Canon, consists of the Vinaya Pitaka (rules for monastic life), the Sutta Pitaka (Buddha's discourses), and the Abhidhamma Pitaka (philosophical and doctrinal analysis). The Jataka tales, while important, are separate texts that recount the previous lives of the Buddha.

fields.question: The original name of the sect which later came to be known as Jaina was
fields.explanation: The Jaina sect was originally known as the Nigranthas. The term 'Nigrantha' means 'free from bonds' and was used to describe the followers of Jainism who had renounced worldly attachments and pursuits.

fields.question: According to Ceylonese tradition, Buddha's Parinirbana took place in
fields.explanation: According to Ceylonese tradition, Buddha's Parinirvana (the final deathless state) took place in 483 B.C. This date is significant in the Buddhist tradition and marks the end of the Buddha's earthly life.

fields.question: Which of the following was a Buddhist genealogical text?
fields.explanation: The Dipavamsa is one of the earliest Buddhist historical texts, written in Pali. It provides a genealogical and historical account of Buddhism and the history of the island of Sri Lanka.

fields.question: The decline of the Nandas at the hands of Kautilya and Chandragupta Maurya has been vividly portrayed in the Sanskrit Play
fields.explanation: The Mudrarakshasa is a Sanskrit play by Vishakhadatta that narrates the rise of Chandragupta Maurya to power with the help of his advisor Kautilya. The play provides a detailed account of the political intrigue and strategies used to overthrow the Nanda dynasty.

fields.question: Allahabad pillar inscription carved by
fields.explanation: The Allahabad Pillar inscription, also known as the Prayag Prashasti, was carved by Harisena, the court poet and minister of the Gupta emperor Samudragupta. The inscription provides a detailed account of Samudragupta's reign and achievements.

fields.question: Who composed Allahabad Prasasti?
fields.explanation: Harisena, also known as Harishena, was a 4th-century Sanskrit poet, panegyrist, and government minister. He was an important figure in the court of the Gupta emperor, Samudragupta. His most famous poem, written around 345 C.E., describes the bravery of Samudragupta and is inscribed on the Allahabad Pillar.

fields.question: To which period of Indian history did Aryabhatta and Varahamihira (Scientist and Mathematician respectively) belong?
fields.explanation: Aryabhata and Varahamihira were prominent figures of the Gupta period. Aryabhata wrote the Aryabhatiya and is credited with the invention of the decimal system and zero. Varahamihira authored the Brihat Samhita, an encyclopedic work covering various aspects of astrology, astronomy, and other sciences.

fields.question: Who among the following said 'All men are my Children' and just as I desire happiness in those worlds and the next, so also I desire to all men?
fields.explanation: Ashoka, the Mauryan emperor, expressed his compassionate and paternal view of his subjects in his edicts. He promoted the welfare and happiness of his people and propagated the principles of Dharma (righteousness).

fields.question: Lion capital in currency notes was discovered from
fields.explanation: The Lion Capital of Ashoka, which is featured on Indian currency notes, was discovered at Sarnath. This iconic sculpture was originally erected atop an Ashokan pillar and is now the national emblem of India.

fields.question: The Lion capital of currency notes was discovered from
fields.explanation: The Lion Capital of Ashoka, found at Sarnath, is a significant symbol of India's heritage. It represents the teachings of Buddha and is a notable example of Mauryan sculpture.

fields.question: Who among the Gupta rulers was known as 'Lichchavidauhitra'?
fields.explanation: Samudragupta was referred to as 'Lichchavidauhitra', meaning 'son of the Lichchavi daughter'. He was the son of Chandragupta I and Kumaradevi, a Lichchavi princess. He is known for his military conquests and patronage of the arts.

fields.question: Chandragupta Maurya defeated
fields.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya defeated Seleucus I Nicator, a general of Alexander the Great, and secured additional territories west of the Indus River. This victory established the Maurya Empire as a dominant force in ancient India.

fields.question: Who introduces Kulinism?
fields.explanation: Kulinism, a set of Hindu caste and marriage rules, was introduced by Raja Ballal Sena of Bengal. It aimed to maintain the purity of high-status groups by regulating marriages within the same or higher social classes.

fields.question: Fo-Kuo-King was authored by whom?
fields.explanation: Fa-Hien, a Chinese Buddhist monk, authored 'Fo-Kuo-King' (Record of Buddhist Kingdoms) after his travels to India during the reign of Chandragupta II. His work provides valuable insights into the social, religious, and cultural conditions of India at that time.

fields.question: Who was Megasthenes?
fields.explanation: Megasthenes was the Greek ambassador of Seleucus I Nicator to the court of Chandragupta Maurya. His accounts, compiled in the work 'Indica', provide valuable information about the Mauryan Empire and its administration.

fields.question: The Mauryan ruler who used the name 'Piyadasi' in his official declarations was
fields.explanation: Ashoka, the Mauryan emperor, used the name 'Piyadasi' (meaning 'beloved of the gods') in his edicts. These edicts reflect his policies and commitment to the welfare of his subjects and the propagation of Buddhism.

fields.question: Si-Yu-Ki was authored by
fields.explanation: Huen-Tsang, a Chinese Buddhist monk, authored 'Si-Yu-Ki' (Records of the Western World) during his travels to India in the 7th century. His detailed account of the Indian subcontinent during Harshavardhana's reign is an important historical source.

fields.question: The Vikramasila-Vihara was founded by
fields.explanation: Dharmapala, a Pala emperor, founded the Vikramasila Vihara, a major Buddhist monastic university. It became one of the most important centers of Buddhist learning in India during the Pala period.

fields.question: The first historical emperor of ancient India was
fields.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya is often considered the first historical emperor of ancient India. He established the Maurya Empire after overthrowing the Nanda dynasty and expanded his kingdom significantly through military conquests and strategic alliances.

fields.question: Who was known as Amitraghata?
fields.explanation: Bindusara, the second Mauryan emperor and father of Ashoka, was known as Amitraghata, which means 'Slayer of enemies'. He continued the expansion of the Maurya Empire and maintained its dominance in the Indian subcontinent.

fields.question: Who was the founder of the Gupta dynasty?
fields.explanation: The Gupta Empire emerged around the late 3rd century under the control of its founding member Srigupta. He was succeeded by his son Ghatotkacha Gupta. The empire rose to prominence during the reign of Chandragupta I (319-335 CE).

fields.question: Surya Siddhanta was authored by?
fields.explanation: The original writer of Surya Siddhanta is unknown. There are several works with the same name. Varahamihira summarized the Surya Siddhanta in his book Panchasiddhantika.

fields.question: According to Buddhist tradition, Chandragupta Maurya belonged to the Maurya tribe of
fields.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya, according to Buddhist tradition, belonged to the Kshatriya caste, which is the warrior and ruler class in the varna system of ancient India.

fields.question: Which of the following Gupta rulers was known as Vikramaditya?
fields.explanation: Chandragupta II, also known as Vikramaditya, was one of the most powerful and celebrated rulers of the Gupta dynasty. His reign marked a golden age of cultural and scientific advancements.

fields.question: In his inscriptions, Ashoka calls himself
fields.explanation: Ashoka, in his inscriptions, referred to himself as 'Devanampriya Priyadarsin', which means 'Beloved of the Gods, He who looks on with Affection'. These inscriptions reflect his commitment to the welfare of his subjects and the propagation of Dharma.

fields.question: The Kalinga war is mentioned in the
fields.explanation: The Kalinga war is mentioned in Rock Edict No. 13, where Ashoka describes the horrors of the war and his subsequent embrace of Buddhism and non-violence. This edict is located in Shahbazgarhi and Mansehra.

fields.question: The University of Vikramshila was established by
fields.explanation: Dharmapala, the Pala emperor, established the Vikramshila University, which became one of the most important centers of Buddhist learning in India during the Pala period.

fields.question: Chandragupta Maurya was succeeded by
fields.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya was succeeded by his son Bindusara, who ruled from 297 BCE to 273 BCE and was the father of Ashoka.

fields.question: The famous mathematician of ancient India was
fields.explanation: Aryabhatta was a renowned mathematician and astronomer of ancient India. He is best known for his work Aryabhatiya, which covers various topics in mathematics and astronomy.

fields.question: Who among the following transferred his royal residence permanently from Rajgriha to Pataliputra?
fields.explanation: Udayin, a king of the Haryanka dynasty, transferred his royal residence permanently from Rajgriha to Pataliputra, which later became a major center of political and cultural activity in ancient India.

fields.question: Sandhyakar Nandi was
fields.option4: Court poet of Chandra Gupta II
fields.explanation: Sandhyakar Nandi was the writer of Ramcharita Kavya, an important literary work of ancient India.

fields.question: The greatest scholar of Medical Science during Ancient India
fields.explanation: Charaka was one of the principal contributors to Ayurveda, an ancient system of medicine. He is the author of the Charaka Samhita, a foundational text of Ayurveda.

fields.question: Sasanka belonged to the
fields.explanation: Sasanka was a king of the Gauda Kingdom and is known as the first independent ruler of Bengal. His capital was Karnasubarna, located in present-day Murshidabad, West Bengal.

fields.question: Gopal was the founder of
fields.explanation: Gopala was the founder of the Pala dynasty, which ruled over the eastern regions of the Indian subcontinent, primarily in present-day Bengal and Bihar.

fields.question: Chalukya's established their empire in
fields.explanation: The Chalukyas established their empire in the Deccan region of India. They were known for their architectural achievements and contributions to art and culture.

fields.question: An important port in the time of Satavahanas was
fields.explanation: Sopara was an important port during the time of the Satavahanas. It played a significant role in trade and commerce in ancient India.

fields.question: Indica was written by
fields.explanation: Indica was written by Megasthenes, a Greek ambassador to the court of Chandragupta Maurya. His work provides valuable insights into the Mauryan Empire and its society.

fields.question: The 'Ratha temples' of Mahabalipuram were constructed in the reign of
fields.explanation: The 'Ratha temples', also known as Pancha Rathas, of Mahabalipuram were constructed during the reign of Narasimhavarman I of the Pallava dynasty. These temples are renowned for their architectural beauty.

fields.question: Who among the following persons wrote Mitakshara?
fields.explanation: Mitakshara, a legal commentary on the Yajnavalkya Smriti, was written by Vijnanesvara. It is considered one of the main authorities on Hindu law.

fields.question: The Khalimpur Copper Plate informs us about the military exploits of the Pala ruler
fields.explanation: The Khalimpur Copper Plate provides information about the military exploits of Dharmapala, a ruler of the Pala dynasty. He was known for his patronage of Buddhism and educational institutions.

fields.question: Who constructed the Rajrajeshwara Temple?
fields.explanation: The Rajrajeshwara Temple, a Shiva temple located in Kerala, was built by Raja Raja I, a Chola emperor. He is also known for constructing the Brihadisvara Temple in Thanjavur. He was an able administrator who conquered Ceylon (Sri Lanka).

fields.question: Under whose Patronage was Kailas Temple at Ellora constructed?
fields.explanation: The Kailas Temple at Ellora, a rock-cut Hindu temple in Maharashtra, was constructed under the patronage of the Rashtrakuta king Krishna I in the eighth century.

fields.question: Who was the Chola King to have conquered Bengal?
fields.explanation: Rajendra Chola I was one of the greatest rulers of the Chola dynasty. He conquered Bengal and assumed the title of 'Gangaikonda Cholapuram' or 'Ganga Winner Chola King', as recorded in Tanjore and Tirumala inscriptions.

fields.question: Ankor Wat' was built by
fields.explanation: Angkor Wat, the largest religious monument in the world, located in Cambodia, was initially a Hindu temple dedicated to Vishnu for the Khmer Empire. It was built by Suryavarman II and later transformed into a Buddhist temple.

fields.question: Who was the founder of the Satvahana Dynasty?
fields.explanation: Simuk is recognized as the founder of the Satavahana dynasty, which established its rule in the Deccan region.

fields.question: Who was the Kaivartta chief who rebelled against the Pala ruler Mahipala II of Bengal?
fields.explanation: The Varendra rebellion was led by the Kaivartta chief Divya against King Mahipala II. The rebellion resulted in the capture of Varendra, which was later recaptured by King Rampala with the assistance of neighboring vassals.

fields.question: The author of Kadambari was
fields.explanation: Banabhatta is the author of Kadambari, a renowned classical Sanskrit novel.

fields.question: Which King founded Vikramasila University?
fields.explanation: Dharmapala, the Pala emperor, founded Vikramasila University, which became an important center of Buddhist learning.

fields.question: Who of the following were the first rulers to make land grants to the Brahmanas?
fields.explanation: The Satavahana dynasty was among the first to make land grants to Brahmanas, a practice that became common in ancient India.

fields.question: Who issued the Nasik Inscription?
fields.explanation: The Nasik Inscription was issued by Gautami Balashree, the mother of Gautamiputra Satkarni, documenting the achievements of her son, the greatest ruler of the Satavahana dynasty.

fields.question: Who among the following kings performed Asvamedh Yagya?
fields.explanation: Pulakesin II, the Chalukya king, performed the Asvamedh Yagya, a Vedic horse sacrifice ritual symbolizing the sovereign power of the king.

fields.question: Identify the dynasty which ruled over the Malay Archipelago
fields.explanation: The Sailendra dynasty ruled over the Malay Archipelago and was known for its significant influence in Southeast Asia, including the construction of the Borobudur temple in Java.

fields.question: Who issued the Nasik Prasasti (Inscription)?
fields.explanation: The Nasik Prasasti was issued by Gautamiputra Satkarni, detailing his achievements and victories.

fields.question: The Gandhara School of Art is associated with
fields.explanation: The Gandhara School of Art, characterized by its Greco-Buddhist style, flourished under the patronage of the Kushan emperor Kanishka.

fields.question: Who is known as 'Kunik' in the history of India?
fields.explanation: Ajatashatru, the ruler of Magadha, is known as 'Kunik' or 'Pitruhanta' (father-killer) for having ascended the throne after killing his father. He later embraced Buddhism and convened the first Buddhist council at Rajagriha in 483 BC.

fields.question: Who wrote Buddhacharita?
fields.explanation: Asvaghosa is credited with writing Buddhacharita.

fields.question: The founder of Nanda Dynasty was
fields.explanation: Mahapadma is known as the founder of the Nanda Dynasty.

fields.question: The 1st capital of Magadh was
fields.explanation: The first capital of Magadh was Rajagriha, identified with Girivraja.

fields.question: The author of 'Kadambari' was
fields.explanation: Banabhatta is known as the author of 'Kadambari'.

fields.question: Whose contemporary was the famous grammarian Patanjali?
fields.explanation: Patanjali, the famous grammarian, was a contemporary of Pushya Mitra Sunga.

fields.question: Paragal Khan helped in bringing the first ever Bengali translation of the
fields.explanation: Paragal Khan facilitated the Bengali translation of the Mahabharata.

fields.question: Amir Khasru was the Court Poet of
fields.explanation: Amir Khasru served as the Court Poet of Alauddin Khilji.

fields.question: Which of the following are true with regard to the Gandhara School of Art?
fields.option1: It was also known as Buddhist Art
fields.option2: Its figures were superior to the Mathura School of Art
fields.option3: Buddha's figure appears here for the first time
fields.option4: Its craftsmen used white stone to make images
fields.answer: Buddha's figure appears here for the first time
fields.explanation: The Gandhara School of Art is notable for presenting Buddha's figure for the first time.

fields.question: Who among the following Sultans of Delhi wanted to become Second Alexander and conquer the world?
fields.explanation: Alauddin Khilji harbored ambitions to emulate Alexander the Great and conquer the world.

fields.question: Alexander fought against the Purus on the banks of the river
fields.explanation: Alexander fought against the Purus on the banks of the river Jhelum.

fields.question: Who was given the title of Andhra - Kavita Pitamaha?
fields.explanation: Peddan was given the title of Andhra - Kavita Pitamaha.

fields.question: Who was the author of the book Tarikh-i-Firuz Shahi?
fields.explanation: Tarikh-i-Firuz Shahi was authored by Ziauddin Barani.

fields.question: Sher Shah died while attacking?
fields.explanation: Sher Shah died while attacking Kalinjar.

fields.question: When did Ikhtiyaruddin Bakhtiyar Khalji invade Bengal?
fields.explanation: Ikhtiyaruddin Bakhtiyar Khalji invaded Bengal in 1202 A.D.

fields.question: Who was the General of Sher Shah?
fields.explanation: Brahmajit Gaur was the General of Sher Shah.

fields.question: Who caused to build Qutub Minar in Delhi?
fields.explanation: Qutbuddin Aibak caused to build Qutub Minar in Delhi.

fields.question: Name the Sultan who introduced Rationing System in India
fields.explanation: Alauddin Khalji introduced the Rationing System in India.

fields.question: Sakabda was started in
fields.explanation: Sakabda was started in 78 A.D by Kanishka.

fields.question: The battle of Tarain was fought between Muhammad Ghuri and
fields.explanation: The battle of Tarain was fought between Muhammad Ghuri and Prithviraj Chauhan.

fields.question: With whom of the following did Shivaji sign the Treaty of Purandhar in 1665 A.D?
fields.explanation: Shivaji signed the Treaty of Purandhar in 1665 A.D with Jaisingh.

fields.question: Which part of Rig Veda considered to be written in later Vedic age?
fields.explanation: The 10th mandala of Rig Veda is considered to be written in the later Vedic age.

fields.question: Satyameva Jayate was taken from which book?
fields.explanation: The phrase 'Satyameva Jayate' is from the Mundaka Upanishad.

fields.question: What is the meaning of the word 'Tripitaka'?
fields.explanation: Tripitaka means 'three baskets', referring to the three categories of Buddhist scriptures.

fields.question: Dadashanga contains religious preach of?
fields.explanation: Dadashanga contains religious preach of Mahaveera.

fields.question: Vikramankadevacharita contains the achievement of which king?
fields.explanation: Vikramankadevacharita contains the achievements of Vikramaditya VI.

fields.question: Ganjam inscription depicts about which king?
fields.explanation: The Ganjam inscription depicts about Gauda king Sasanka.

fields.question: The conversation between Buddhist monk Nagasena and Bactria king Menander was written in which book?
fields.explanation: The conversation between Nagasena and Menander was written in Milinda Panha.

fields.question: The Aihole inscription was written by?
fields.explanation: The Aihole inscription was written by Rovikirti.

fields.question: Tahkik-i-hind was written by?
fields.explanation: Tahkik-i-hind was written by Alberuni.

fields.question: Ibn Battuta came to India during?
fields.explanation: Ibn Battuta came to India during the reign of Muhammed Bin Tughlak.

fields.question: What is the meaning of Vedas?
fields.explanation: Vedas means knowledge. It is believed that Vedas were not manmade so they are called Apaurusheya. Initially, Vedas were not in written form but were passed down orally, hence they are called Shrutis.

fields.question: Allahabad pillar inscription carved by
fields.explanation: The Allahabad pillar inscription, also known as Prayaga Prasasti, was carved by Harisena, a court poet of Samundragupta. It is written in Sanskrit using Nagari script.

fields.question: At which of the following places has the largest belt of painted rock shelter of pre-historic period been found?
fields.explanation: The largest belt of painted rock shelters of the prehistoric period has been found at Bhimbetka caves in the Raisen District of Madhya Pradesh.

fields.question: Who wrote Milindapanha?
fields.explanation: Milindapanha was written by Nagasena.

fields.question: Who wrote Gitavali, Kavitawali and Vinaya Patrika?
fields.explanation: Gitavali, Kavitawali and Vinaya Patrika were written by Tulsidas.

fields.question: Which school of Art flourished in the region between the lower valleys of Krishna and Godavari during 2nd Century BCE-3rd Century CE?
fields.explanation: The Amravati School of art flourished in the region between the lower valleys of Krishna and Godavari during 2nd Century BCE-3rd Century CE. It is noted for its sculptures made of white marble.

fields.question: Which of the following sources states that Srinagar was built by Asoka?
fields.explanation: Rajatarangini, written by Kalhana in the 12th century CE, states that Srinagar was built by Asoka.

fields.question: Which Magadhan ruler launched a final military assault on the Gana rajyas of Kasi-Kosal with the help of new weapons like rathamushala and mahasilakantaka?
fields.explanation: Ajatasatru, a Magadhan ruler, launched a final military assault on the Gana rajyas of Kasi-Kosal with the help of new weapons like rathamushala and mahasilakantaka.

fields.explanation: The hereditary soldiers of the Mauryan period were known as Maula.

Who was the author of the book `Tarikh-i-Firuz Shahi'?
fields.explanation: Ziauddin Barani (1285–1358 CE) was a Muslim political thinker of the Delhi Sultanate during Muhammad bin Tughlaq and Firuz Shah's reign. He was best known for composing the Tarikh-i-Firoz Shahi, a work on medieval India, which covers the period from the reign of Ghiyas ud din Balban to the first six years of the reign of Firoz Shah Tughluq. Barani's Fatwa-i-Jahandari provides an example of his extreme views on religion, promoting a hierarchy among Muslim communities in the Indian subcontinent.

fields.question: Sher Shah died while attacking?
fields.explanation: Sher Shah was killed on 22 May 1545 during the siege of Kalinjar fort in Bundelkhand against the Rajputs of Mahoba. When all tactics to subdue this fort failed, Sher Shah ordered the walls of the fort to be blown up with gunpowder, but he himself was seriously wounded as a result of the explosion of a mine.

fields.question: When did Ikhtiyaruddin Bakhtiyar Khalij invade Bengal?
fields.explanation: Ikhtiaruddin bin Bakhtiyar Khilji invaded Bengal in the year 1201 A.D. He was also known as Muhammad Bakhtiyar Khalji. His invasions critically damaged the establishments made by the Buddhists at Odantapuri, Nalanda, and Vikramashila. He invaded Nabadwip and later defeated King Laxmansena in 1203. He also captured the Gaur city, which was the capital at that time.

fields.question: Who was the General of Sher Shah?
fields.explanation: The general of Sher Shah was Brahmajit Gaur, who was Hindu. Jaisingh was a mansabdar of Akbar.

fields.question: Who caused to build Qutub Minar in Delhi?
fields.explanation: Qutub Minar was built in memory of a sufi sant. It was started by Qutbuddin Aibak and later finished by Iltutmish.

fields.question: The battle of Tarain was fought between Muhammad Ghuri and
fields.explanation:
Battle of Tarain may refer to any of the following battles fought at Tarain (modern Taraori in Haryana, India):
• First Battle of Tarain (1191), in which the Chahamana king Prithviraj Chauhan defeated the Ghurid sultan Mu'izz al-Din (Muhammad of Ghor or Muhammad Ghori)
• Second Battle of Tarain (1192), in which the Muhammad Ghori defeated the Prithviraj Chauhan
• Third Battle of Tarain (1216), in which the Mamluk (Slave dynasty) king Iltutmish of the Delhi Sultanate defeated and captured the former Ghurid general Taj al-Din Yildiz

fields.question: With whom of the following did Shivaji sign the Treaty of Purandhar in 1665 A.D
fields.explanation: The Treaty of Purandar was signed on June 11, 1665 AD between Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Raja Jai Singh of Amber, who was deputed by Mughal emperor Aurangazeb. By this treaty, Shivaji surrendered 23 out of 35 forts and the Mughals acknowledged the authority of Shivaji over Konkan and parts of Balaghat.

The meaning of the word Mansab is
fields.explanation: The Mansabdar was a military unit within the administrative system of the Mughal Empire introduced by Akbar. The system determined the rank, status, salaries & allowances of a government official and military generals. The term manasabadar means a person having a mansab. (which means a role) In the mansabdari system founded by Akbar. Those mansabdars whose rank was one thousand or below were called Amir, while those above 1,000 were called Amir-al Kabir (Great Amir). Some great Amirs whose ranks were above 5,000 were also given the title of Amir-al Umara (Amir of Amirs).
