fields.question: The summer and winter seasons in a year are caused by
fields.option1: aphelion (farthest) and perihelion (nearest) positions of the Earth from the Sun during the annual revolution
fields.option2: rotation of the Earth on its axis
fields.option4: revolution of the Earth on its inclined axis
fields.answer: revolution of the Earth on its inclined axis
fields.explanation: The summer and winter seasons are caused by the revolution of the Earth on its inclined axis.

fields.question: DIRECTIONS: The following question consists of two statements, statement I and statement II. You are to examine these two statements carefully and select the answers to these items using the code given below. Statement I: Doldrums is a calm belt between 5°N and 5°S of the equator. Statement II: The sun rays strike almost vertically over the equator throughout the year. Code:
fields.option1: Both the statements are individually true and Statement II is the correct explanation of Statement I
fields.option2: Both the statements are individually true but Statement II is not correct explanation of Statement I
fields.option3: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
fields.option4: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
fields.answer: Both the statements are individually true but Statement II is not correct explanation of Statement I
fields.explanation: While both statements are true, the vertical sun rays are not the direct cause of the doldrums.

fields.question: What would be the date and local time of a place located at 88°30′ E longitude when the local time at 0° longitude is 19.00 hrs. of 28th February 2013?
fields.explanation: At 88°30′ E longitude, the local time would be 00-54 hrs. of 1st March when it is 19:00 hrs. at 0° longitude.

fields.question: The group of stars arranged in a definite pattern is called.
fields.explanation: A group of stars arranged in a definite pattern is called a constellation.

fields.question: Which is the smallest planet of solar system?
fields.explanation: Mercury is the smallest planet in the solar system.

fields.question: Which of the following correctly explains Kepler’s first law of Planetary Motion?
fields.option1: All the planets move in elliptical orbits with the sun at a focus
fields.option2: The radius vector from the sun to the planet sweeps equal area in equal time
fields.option3: The square of the time period of a planet is proportional to the cube of the semimajor axis of the ellipse
fields.answer: All the planets move in elliptical orbits with the sun at a focus
fields.explanation: Kepler’s first law states that all the planets move in elliptical orbits with the sun at one focus.

fields.question: Carbon is the ........... most abundant element in the earth’s crust.
fields.explanation: Carbon is the 14th most abundant element in the earth’s crust.

fields.question: Which one of the following is not a metamorphic rock?
fields.explanation: Conglomerate is a sedimentary rock, not a metamorphic rock.

fields.question: Which one of the following is an example of a block mountain?
fields.explanation: The Black Forest is an example of a block mountain.

fields.question: Telegraph plateau is a part of
fields.explanation: The Telegraph Plateau is part of the North Atlantic Ridge.

fields.question: Which of the following pairs is most suitable for ascertaining the origin of the rocks?
fields.explanation: The most suitable pairs for ascertaining the origin of the rocks are their structure and composition.

fields.question: During volcanic eruption deposition of lava in anticlines and synclines of folded mountains accounts for formation of
fields.explanation: During volcanic eruption, the deposition of lava in anticlines and synclines of folded mountains accounts for the formation of a phacolith.

fields.question: When following fissures in the rocks, its both parts slide in front and one part slides over the other, the resulting feature is
fields.explanation: When fissures in the rocks cause both parts to slide and one part to slide over the other, the resulting feature is a reverse fault.

fields.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding the citizenship of India?
fields.explanation: A person born in India on or after 26th January 1950 but before 1st July, 1987 is a citizen of India by birth irrespective of the nationality of his parents.

fields.question: Indian constitution took the concept of single citizenship from?
fields.explanation: The concept of single citizenship in India has been inspired from the United Kingdom’s constitution.

fields.question: What is true about NRC?
fields.explanation: The National Register of Citizens, 1951 is a register that was prepared after the conduct of the Census of 1951 in each village and house of India. It shows the houses or holdings in a serial order and indicates against each house, the number and names of persons staying therein. NRC along with Electoral Roll is called the Legacy Data.

fields.question: Which committee gave the idea of jus soli kind of citizenship?
fields.explanation: Motilal Nehru Committee in 1928 came in favour of the concept of jus soli for the first time.

fields.question: In which list of the Indian Constitution is the Citizenship included?
fields.explanation: Citizenship is listed in the Union List under the Constitution of India.

fields.question: The Constitution defines citizens as?
fields.option2: Any person who spends more than 5 years in India
fields.option3: Any person who is born in India or his/her parents are born in India
fields.explanation: The Constitution does not define the term ‘citizen’ but entails the various categories of persons entitled to citizenship in Part 2.

fields.question: Which article of the Constitution contains the provisions of citizenship to persons migrated to India from Pakistan?
fields.explanation: Article 6 provides for the rights of citizenship of certain people who have migrated to India from Pakistan.

fields.question: Indian citizenship can be acquired through which of the following?
fields.explanation: Indian Citizenship can be acquired by descent, naturalization and by registration. The provisions for these have been listed in Part 2 of the Constitution.

fields.question: When was the Citizenship Amendment Bill passed by the Parliament?
fields.explanation: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 was passed by the Parliament of India on 11 December 2019.

fields.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Citizenship Amendment Act 2019?
fields.explanation: Citizenship Amendment Act 2019 amends the Citizenship Act of 1955. Indian citizenship for persecuted religious minorities from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan who are Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis or Christians but not Muslims. They must have entered India before December 2014.

fields.question: Who appoints the Advocate General of states?
fields.option3: Chief justice of the high court
fields.explanation: The Advocate General is appointed by the Governor of the respective state.

fields.question: Who does the Chief Minister give his resignation to?
fields.option3: Chief justice of the High Court
fields.explanation: The Chief Minister's resignation is to be accepted or rejected by the Governor of the state. It is handed over to him/her by the CM.

fields.question: Which among the following statements concerning the Chief Minister is/are NOT true?
fields.explanation: The chief minister is elected through a majority in the state legislative assembly. The Chief Minister after his appointment also has to prove his/her majority whenever there is a floor test.

fields.question: The powers and functions of the Chief Minister of the state are analogous to which of the following?
fields.explanation: The Chief Minister of the state has powers analogous to the Prime minister of the Union.

fields.question: What is the minimum age to become the Chief Minister of any State?
fields.explanation: To become the Chief Minister one must be 25 years of age or more.

fields.question: Constitutional government stands for
fields.option2: a government limited by the desires and capacities of those who exercise power
fields.option3: a government run according to general laws known to the people
fields.option4: a government run by people’s representatives
fields.explanation: Constitutional government means a government that is limited by a constitution.

fields.question: Which item is wrongly matched?
fields.option2: November 26, 1949- The people of India adopted, enacted and gave to themselves the Constitution
fields.option3: January 24, 1950- The Constitution was signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly
fields.option4: January 26, 1950- the date of commencement of the Constitution
fields.explanation: The Constituent Assembly first met on December 9, 1946, not 1947.

fields.question: Which feature and source are WRONGLY matched?
fields.explanation: Judicial review in India is borrowed from the US Constitution, not the British practice.

fields.question: Which one among the following has the power to regulate the right of citizenship in India?
fields.explanation: The Parliament may regulate the right of citizenship of India through the amendment of the Citizenship Act.

fields.question: What is extradition?
fields.option1: Delivering a national of another country for the trial of offences
fields.option2: To block the trade of other countries with a particular country
fields.option3: Forcing a person to leave the country of which he is a citizen
fields.option4: To force foreign national to leave the country
fields.answer: Delivering a national of another country for the trial of offences
fields.explanation: Extradition is the process of delivering a national of another country for the trial of offences.

fields.question: “Referendum” has an integral relationship with
fields.explanation: A referendum is a direct vote in which an entire electorate is asked to either accept or reject a particular proposal.

fields.question: Which of the following statements best describe systems of liberal democracy?
fields.option1: Liberal democratic political systems only occur in highly industrialized societies.
fields.option2: The same political party holds power continuously in liberal democratic regimes.
fields.option3: Liberal democratic governments prevent their citizens from traveling abroad.
fields.option4: Liberal democratic governments protect basic civil liberties.
fields.answer: Liberal democratic governments protect basic civil liberties.
fields.explanation: In liberal democracies, citizens have rights such as freedom of speech, freedom of association, and the freedom to choose their political representatives.

fields.question: The mention of the word ‘justice’ in the preamble to the constitution of India expresses
fields.explanation: The preamble of the Indian Constitution mentions 'justice' as social, economic, and political justice.

fields.question: In which case did the Supreme Court evolve the concept of ‘Basic Structure of Constitution’?
fields.explanation: The concept of the 'Basic Structure' of the Constitution was evolved in the Keshavananda Bharati case.

fields.question: By which amendment of the constitution, the word ‘Socialist’ was incorporated in the preamble of the constitution?
fields.explanation: The word ‘Socialist’ was incorporated into the preamble of the Indian Constitution by the 42nd Amendment.

fields.question: Which one of the following rights has been described by Dr. Ambedkar as ‘The heart and soul of the constitution’?
fields.explanation: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar described the Right to Constitutional Remedies as ‘The heart and soul of the Constitution’.

fields.question: Which schedule of the Indian Constitution is related to Panchayati Raj?
fields.explanation: The XI Schedule of the Indian Constitution is related to Panchayati Raj.

fields.question: Which term is not used in the preamble of the Indian Constitution?
fields.explanation: The term 'Federal' is not used in the preamble of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: The source of the basic structure theory of the constitution of India is
fields.explanation: The basic structure theory of the constitution of India is derived from judicial interpretation.

fields.question: The provision of the sixth schedule shall not apply in which one of the following states?
fields.explanation: The provision of the Sixth Schedule does not apply to the state of Goa.

fields.question: Which one of the following is not related to the constitutional government?
fields.explanation: Hierarchy government is not related to the concept of constitutional government.

fields.question: The Indian constitution is divided into
fields.explanation: The Indian Constitution is divided into 22 chapters.

fields.question: Which of the states of Indian federation has a separate constitution?
fields.explanation: The state of Jammu & Kashmir has a separate constitution. Article 370 of the Indian constitution grants special status to Jammu and Kashmir.

fields.question: Which one of the following is not a part of the ‘basic structure’ of the Indian constitution?
fields.explanation: The parliamentary form of government is not considered a part of the basic structure of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: The philosophical foundation of the Indian constitution is
fields.explanation: The Preamble lays the philosophical foundation of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: Which article of the Indian constitution declares Devnagri Hindi as an official language of India?
fields.explanation: Article 343 of the Indian Constitution declares Devnagri Hindi as the official language of India.

fields.question: Which of the following gave the idea of a Constituent Assembly for India?
fields.explanation: The Cabinet Mission Plan gave the idea of a Constituent Assembly for India.

fields.question: Who amongst the following was not a member of the drafting committee of the constitution?
fields.explanation: J.L. Nehru was not a member of the drafting committee of the constitution.

fields.question: The tenth schedule of the Indian constitution deals with
fields.option4: Distribution of powers between the union and states
fields.explanation: The tenth schedule of the Indian constitution deals with anti-defection legislation.

fields.question: The number of official languages recognized under the 8th schedule of the Indian Constitution is
fields.explanation: There are twenty-two official languages recognized under the 8th schedule of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: How many articles are there in the Indian constitution?
fields.explanation: The Indian Constitution originally had 395 articles.

fields.question: The feature of the Indian constitution borrowed from the South African constitution is
fields.option2: Procedure for amendment of constitution and election of Rajya Sabha members
fields.answer: Procedure for amendment of constitution and election of Rajya Sabha members
fields.explanation: The Indian constitution borrowed the procedure for amendment of the constitution and the election of Rajya Sabha members from the South African constitution.

fields.question: The words justice in the form of social, economic, and political justice present in the Preamble has been taken from
fields.explanation: The words 'justice' in the form of social, economic, and political justice present in the Preamble has been taken from the Russian Revolution.

fields.question: The terms not introduced in the Preamble through the 42nd amendment are:
fields.explanation: All the terms 'Socialist', 'Secular', and 'Integrity' were introduced in the Preamble through the 42nd amendment.

fields.question: Which case determined that the Preamble is a part of the constitution?
fields.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati case determined that the Preamble is a part of the constitution.

fields.question: Which statements are correct?
fields.option1: Originally the constitution had 14 languages in the 8th schedule.
fields.option2: Currently, there are 22 languages with the last amendment being the 92nd amendment.
fields.explanation: Originally the constitution had 14 languages in the 8th schedule, and currently, there are 22 languages with the last amendment being the 92nd amendment.

fields.question: Which statements are correct?
fields.option1: Article 2 of the constitution gives the right to the government to create new states into the Union of India which are not part of India already.
fields.option2: Article 3 gives the power to the government to change the boundaries of the state within India.
fields.explanation: Article 2 gives the government the right to create new states into the Union of India which are not part of India already, and Article 3 gives the power to the government to change the boundaries of the states within India.

fields.question: The parliament can make any law for the whole or any part of India for implementing international treaties?
fields.option1: with the consent of all the states
fields.option2: with the consent of the majority of states
fields.option3: with the consent of the state concerned
fields.option4: without the consent of any state.
fields.answer: without the consent of any state
fields.explanation: Article 253 gives the Parliament the power to make any law for the whole or any part of the country or territory of India for implementing any treaty, agreement, or convention with any other country or any decision made at any international conference, association, or other body without the consent of any state.

fields.question: Under which one of the following constitution amendment acts, four languages were added to the languages under the eighth schedule of the constitution of India thereby, raising their number to 22?
fields.explanation: Under the 92nd Amendment Act, four languages Bodo, Dogri, Santhali, and Maithili were added to the languages under the eighth schedule of the constitution of India, thereby raising the total number of languages listed in the schedule to 22.

fields.question: Who among the following was the advisor of the Drafting Committee of the Constituent Assembly?
fields.explanation: The advisor of the drafting committee of the constituent assembly was Sir B.N. Rao.

fields.question: A Constitutional government by definition is a
fields.explanation: A Constitutional Government is one which is organized, controlled and limited by the Constitution of the country and not operated by the views of any individual or any political party but regulated only by the law of the land.

fields.question: The theory of Separation of powers was advocated by which of the following political and constitutional philosopher:
fields.explanation: Montesquieu in his book ‘The Spirit of Laws’ expressed his displeasure with the divine right of kingship. He advocated what we now know as separation of powers.

fields.question: The Parliamentary form of Government was first introduced in which country?
fields.explanation: The Parliamentary form of Government was first introduced in Great Britain (UK). The first British Parliament was convened in 1215 with the creation and signing of the ‘Magna Carta’. The feature of Indian Parliamentary form of government has been borrowed from Britain.

fields.question: Which of the following is not correct regarding Indian political system?
fields.explanation: India has Parliamentary form of government where head of the State is President. The executive authority of the President is exercised by the Prime Minister and his council of ministers. The council of ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.

fields.question: Which of the following statement is correct?
The Indian Parliamentary system is different from British Parliamentary system in that India has
fields.option1: (a) Both a real and a nominal executive
fields.explanation: The system of judicial review in Indian Parliamentary system provides power to judiciary to review and determine the validity of a law. It has been taken from the Constitution of America. This special feature is not available in British Parliamentary system.

fields.question: Which one of the following points differentiates the Indian Parliamentary system from the British Parliamentary system?
fields.explanation: Judicial review is a distinguishing feature of the Indian Parliamentary system compared to the British system.

fields.question: The Indian Parliamentary system is different from British Parliamentary system in that India has
fields.option1: (a) Both a real and a nominal executive
fields.explanation: The system of judicial review in Indian Parliamentary system provides power to judiciary to review and determine the validity of a law. It has been taken from the Constitution of America. This special feature is not available in British Parliamentary system.

fields.question: Which one of the following points differentiates the Indian Parliamentary system from the British Parliamentary system?
fields.explanation: Judicial review is a distinguishing feature of the Indian Parliamentary system compared to the British system.

fields.question: Under the Indian political system executive works under______?
fields.explanation: India adopted Parliamentary form of democracy in which executive works under legislature.

fields.question: Which one of the following in Indian polity is an essential feature that indicates that it is federal in character?
fields.option1: (a) The independence of judiciary is safeguarded.
fields.option2: (b) The Union Legislature has elected representatives from constituent units.
fields.option3: (c) The Union Cabinet can have elected representatives from regional parties.
fields.option4: (d) The Fundamental Rights are enforceable by Courts of Law.
fields.explanation: The independence of judiciary is one of the federal features of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: The federal feature of the Indian Constitution includes:
fields.explanation: (1), (2), and (3) are federal features of the Indian Constitution.

fields.question: There is a Parliamentary System of Government in India because the
fields.option1: (a) Lok Sabha is elected directly by the people
fields.option4: (d) Council of Ministers is responsible to the Lok Sabha
fields.explanation: India has parliamentary system of government. In parliamentary system of government, government is responsible to Lok Sabha.

fields.question: The Swaran Singh committee considered the question of
fields.option1: (a) More authority to Punjab on the model of Jammu & Kashmir
fields.option2: (b) The suitability of the Presidential form of Government in India
fields.option3: (c) The precedence of Directive Principles over Fundamental Rights
fields.explanation: The Swaran Singh committee considered the question of the precedence of directive principles over Fundamental Rights.

fields.question: Parliamentary Government works on the principle of-
fields.option3: (c) Close relationship between judiciary and executive
fields.explanation: Parliamentary Governments work on the principle of checks and balances.

fields.question: Which one of the following statements is correct regarding Parliamentary form of Government?
fields.option1: (a) The legislature is responsible to Judiciary.
fields.option2: (b) The Legislature is responsible to Executive.
fields.option3: (c) The Legislature and the Executive are independent.
fields.option4: (d) None of the above/ More than one of the above
fields.explanation: The Parliamentary form of government works on the horizontal distribution of power, which means President, Legislature and Judiciary all are interdependent on each other and bounded by constitution. Hence, None of above options are correct and the legislature controls executive, that means the executive is accountable to legislature.

fields.question: In a Parliamentary system of the Government
fields.explanation: Legislature controls Executive.

fields.question: Which of the following is not characteristic of the Indian Constitution?
fields.explanation: India adopted Parliamentary form of Government, which works on principle of collective responsibility. In India, Judiciary is independent and Constitution of India describes India as ‘Union of States’. Some characteristics of Indian Constitution shows federal characteristics of the Government such as Division of Power Dual government and independent judiciary. The Presidential form of Government is not characteristics of the Indian Constitution. Hence, option (b) is correct.

fields.question: Consider the following statements and choose the correct answer by using the codes given below: Assertion [A] : India is a democratic country. Reason [R] : India has a Constitution of its own Codes :
fields.option1: (a) Both [A] and [R] are true and [R] is the correct explanation of [A]
fields.option2: (b) Both [A] and [R] are true but [R] is not the correct explanation of [A]
fields.explanation: India is a democratic country because Government is elected by people. India has its own constitution. Hence both assertion and reason are correct but reason is not correct explanation of (A).

fields.question: Which of the following institutes are considered necessary to promote ‘Unity among Diversity’ in the Indian Federalism?
fields.option3: (c) Unitary Judicial System & All India Services
fields.explanation: Indian Federalism is a unique example of ‘Unity among Diversity’. Constitution of India is supreme and power is divided between Centre and States. In case of any dispute between Centre and State, several provisions have been made by the Constitution. Inter-State Council is a body set up for strengthening Centre-State and inter State relationship. National Development Council is established for the proper distribution of resources among States. Finance Commission was created to define the financial relations between Centre and State Governments and individual State Governments. Zonal Councils are advisory boards, meant to resolve irritants between Centre and States and amongst States through free and frank discussions and consultations. Judicial system in India is independent and unitary in nature. All India Services (IAS, IPS, IFS) also represent unity among diversity in Indian Federalism.

fields.question: A Federal polity involves
fields.explanation: Federalism is classically defined as a system of governance where there is distribution of power between two levels of government namely central and regional level. Each level of the Government has distinct powers and responsibilities and has a separate system of governance. The relationship between Union and State are well defined in written Constitution. The central and state governments both work together on a variety of issues and programs by mechanism of coordination. In case of a conflict between the Union and the State on any issue, the judiciary has the powers to resolve the disputes.

fields.question: The Constitution of India declares India as
fields.explanation: A Union of States

fields.question: Which of the following determines that the Indian Constitution is Federal?
fields.option3: (c) Vesting of residuary powers with centre
fields.option4: (d) Distribution of powers between Centre and the States
fields.explanation: In the federal system, there is two tier of Government (Center and State) with well assigned power and functions. The Center and State Government work in coordination with each other.

fields.question: Which of the following features of federalism is/are not found in the Indian Constitution?
fields.option3: (iii) Division of power between the Union and the State Governments
fields.explanation: Only (i) and (iv)

fields.question: India is a federal State, how?
fields.option2: (b) Division of power between Center and State
fields.explanation: Division of power between Center and State

fields.question: India is an example of __________ state.
fields.explanation: India is an example of Quasi-Federal state.

fields.question: Under a cabinet form of Government, the cabinet generally remains in office:
fields.option2: (b) So long as it enjoys the confidence of the popular chamber of legislature
fields.option3: (c) So long as it enjoys the confidence of the head of state
fields.option4: (d) So long as it enjoys the confidence of the electorate
fields.explanation: So long as it enjoys the confidence of the popular chamber of legislature

fields.question: In the parliamentary form of Government, the members of the Council of Ministers are collectively responsible to:
fields.option1: (a) The head of the state at his discretion
fields.option3: (c) The head of the state on the recommendations of the head of the government
fields.explanation: The head of the state on the recommendations of the head of the government

fields.question: Which one of the following is not an essential feature of the parliamentary system?
fields.option1: (a) Fusion of the Executive and the Legislature
fields.explanation: Fixed tenure of the executive

fields.question: Assertion (A): Parliamentary system of government is based on the principle of collective responsibility. Reason (R): A parliamentary defeat is not necessarily a sufficient cause for resignation of the Ministry. Codes:
fields.option1: (a) Both A and R are individually true and R is the correct explanation of A
fields.option2: (b) Both A and R are individually true but R is not the correct explanation of A
fields.option3: (c) A is true but R is false
fields.option4: (d) A is false but R is true
fields.explanation: A is true but R is false

fields.question: Consider the following features: Presence of a nominal or titular head of state. Collective responsibility of cabinet Accountability of executive to the legislature Separation of Powers Which of these are the features of a parliamentary form of Government?
fields.explanation: 1, 2 and 3

fields.question: In the absence of the President of India, if Vice President is not available, who of the following can act as the President?
fields.explanation: As per the President (Discharge of Functions) Act 1969, in the event of the occurrence of vacancies in the offices of both the President and the Vice-President by reason in each case of death, resignation or removal or otherwise, the Chief Justice of India or in his absence, the senior most Judge of the Supreme Court of India available, shall discharge the functions of the President until a new President is elected or a new Vice President so elected begins to act as President under Article 65 of the Constitution, whichever is earlier.

fields.question: As per the Article 70 of the Constitution of India, who will be the President in absence of President and Vice President?
At least how many days of prior notice is required for the impeachment of the President of India?
fields.explanation: Article 61 of the Constitution deals with impeachment provision. The President can be removed from office by a process of impeachment for violation of the Constitution. The impeachment charges can be initiated by either house of Parliament. These charges should be signed by one fourth members of the house and a 14 days notice should be given to President.

fields.question: Under which Article of the Constitution of India, impeachment on President can be imposed?
The vacant post of the President is to be filled up within
fields.explanation: According to Article 62(2) of the Constitution, the vacancy for the President shall be filled in no case later than six months from the date of the occurrence of the vacancy.

fields.question: To whom does the President of India submit his resignation?
fields.explanation: According to Article 56 (1) (a) of the Constitution, President shall submit his resignation to the Vice President.

fields.question: The President can vacate his office by addressing his resignation to
Which of the following is part of the Electoral College for the election of the President of India but does not form part of forum for his impeachment?
fields.explanation: The electoral college for election of President consists of elected members of both the houses of Parliament and State Legislative Assemblies. However, State Legislative Assemblies are not part of the impeachment process.

fields.question: The President of India may be removed from his office by the process of impeachment on the basis of which ground?
The President can be impeached on the grounds of violating the Constitution by
fields.option3: The Speaker of the Lok Sabha

fields.question: Vice President of India is elected by an electoral college, consisting of
fields.option1: Members of both the Houses of Parliament
fields.option3: Elected Members of Both the Houses of Parliament
fields.option4: Elected Members of Lok Sabha only
fields.answer: Members of both the Houses of Parliament
fields.explanation: The Vice-President is elected directly, by an electoral college consisting of members (elected as well as nominated) of both Houses of Parliament i.e. Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha by the system of proportional representation using single transferable vote and the voting is by secret ballot.

fields.question: Which of the following qualification are necessary for the office of the Vice President of India as per the Indian Constitution?  (i) The person must be a citizen of India.  (ii) The person must be a member of the Rajya Sabha. (iii) The person must be above 35 years of age.  Select the correct answer using the codes given below.
fields.explanation: The qualification needed to become a VicePresident of India are the following :- • The person must be a citizen of India. • The person must be above 35 years of age. • The person must not hold any office of profit. • The person must be qualified for election as a member of the Rajya Sabha or the Council of States.

fields.question: Electoral College for the 16th Vice Presidential Election of India for 2022 consists of how many members?
fields.explanation: Electoral college of Vice President comprises of 788 members of both Houses of Parliament. Since, all the electors are members of both Houses of Parliament, the value of vote of each member of parliament would be same i.e. 1.

fields.question: Which one of the following did NOT serve as Vice President before assuming the office of the President of India?
fields.explanation: Neelam Sanjiva Reddy was an Indian politician who served as the sixth President of India, serving from 1977 to 1982. He did not serve as Vice President of India before assuming the office of the President of India.

fields.question: Who amongst the following elects the Vice President of India? Select the correct answer from the codes given below: 1. Member of Lok Sabha 2. Member of Rajya Sabha 3. Members of Legislative Assembly 4. Members of Legislative Council
fields.explanation: According to Article 66(1) of the Constitution, the Vice President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the members of both Houses of Parliament in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot.

fields.question: The Vice-President of India is elected by the members of an Electoral College comprising
fields.option1: Only elected members of both Houses of Parliament.
fields.option2: All the members of both Houses of Parliament.
fields.option3: Only elected members of Rajya Sabha and State Assemblies.
fields.option4: Only elected members of State Assemblies.
fields.answer: All the members of both Houses of Parliament.

fields.question: The Vice President of India is elected by
fields.option1: I. The members of Lok Sabha II. The members of Rajya Sabha.
fields.explanation: Kindly refer to the explanation of the above question.

fields.question: The tenure of the Vice President of India is
fields.option4: Dependent on the will of the President
fields.explanation: According to Article 67 of the Constitution, the Vice-President shall hold office for a term of 5 years from the date on which he enters upon his office.

fields.question: Which one of the following statements about the Vice-President of India is incorrect?
fields.option1: The electoral college for election to this office consists of the elected members of both the Houses of Parliament.
fields.option2: He can hold the office of the President for a period not exceeding six months in the absence of the President.
fields.option3: For election to this office a candidate's nomination paper must be subscribed by at least 20 electors as proposers and 20 electors as seconders.
fields.explanation: According to Article 66(1) of the Constitution, the Vice President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the members of both Houses of Parliament. Hence statement 1 is correct. According to Article 65 of the Constitution, the VicePresident acts as President during casual vacancy in the office of the President by reason of death, resignation or removal or otherwise until a new President is elected as soon as practicable and in no case later than six months from the date of occurrence of the vacancy. Hence statement 2 is correct. As per Presidential and Vice-Presidential Elections (Amendment) Act, 1974, which was amended on 5th June, 1997 and as per the new provision, in the case of Vice-Presidential election, at least twenty electors as proposers and at least twenty electors as seconders. Hence statement 3 is also correct.

fields.question: The resolution for removing the VicePresident of India can be moved in the:
fields.explanation: According to Article 67(b) of the Constitution, a Vice President may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Rajya Sabha passed by a majority of all the then Members of the Rajya Sabha and agreed by the Lok Sabha, but no resolution shall be moved unless at least fourteen days prior notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution.

fields.question: Given below are two statements: Statement I: President can dissolve the Lok Sabha on the advice of Speaker. Statement II: Rajya Sabha under Article 312 enjoys special power to appiont members of Human Rights Commission. In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
fields.option1: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
fields.option2: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
fields.option3: Statement I is correct and Statement II in incorrect
fields.option4: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
fields.answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
fields.explanation: President of India has the power to dissolve the Lok Sabha in accordance with the Article 85(2)(b) of the constitution of India. In this matter president acts on the advice of the Prime Minister. Hence, statement (1) is incorrect. As per Article 312 of the Indian Constitution, the Parliament is entitled to create one or more All India Services (including an All India Judicial Service) common to the Union and the States. Hence, statement (2) is also incorrect.

fields.question: Which of the following statements about membership of the Indian Parliament is/are false? (i) For qualifying to the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha, a person must be at least 25 years and 35 years of age respectively. (ii) A person belonging to the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes can contest elections from a general constituency too. (iii) If a member of the Parliament votes against the directions of his/her party, he/she can be deemed to be disqualified on the ground of defection. Select the correct answer using the codes given below.
fields.explanation: The Minimum age eligibility for the Lower House is 25 years on the other hand, to qualify for the Rajya Sabha a candidate needs to be 30 years or above. Hence, statement (1) is false while statements (2) and (3) are true.

fields.question: Who decides disputes regarding disqualification of Members of Parliament?
fields.option4: The President in consultation with the Election Commission
fields.answer: The President in consultation with the Election Commission
fields.explanation: The President of India decides disputes regarding disqualification of Members of Parliament and his decision is final. However, he should obtain the opinion of the election commission and act accordingly.

fields.question: Which State Assembly has the highest number of MLA in India?
fields.explanation: The state of Uttar Pradesh has a bicameral legislature comprising of Legislative Council, an Upper House and Legislative Assembly, the lower House. This is the largest legislature in India. The Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly consists of 403 elected members followed by West Bengal (294) and Maharashtra (289).

fields.question: Which one of the following pairs is NOT correctly matched? State Members in the Legislative Assembly
fields.explanation: Presently, in Manipur legislative assembly, there are 60 members who are directly elected from single-seat constituencies. Rest all the pairs are correctly matched.

fields.question: Under which one of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution, provision of creation or abolition of Legislative Councils in States is made?
fields.explanation: Article 169 of the Constitution is regarding abolition or creation of Legislative Councils in States. According to Article 169 of the Constitution, Parliament may by law provide for the abolition of the Legislative Council of a State having such a Council or for the creation of such a Council in a State having no such Council, if the Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to that effect by a majority of the total membership of the Assembly and by a majority of not less than two third of the members of the Assembly present and voting.

fields.question: Which one of the following States is an exception to the Article 170 as a subject to the provision of the composition of the Legislative Assembly, a State shall consist of not less than sixty members?
fields.explanation: Sikkim became the 22nd State of India by Constitution (Thirty-Sixth Amendment) Act, 1975. The Act provides that the Legislative Assembly of Sikkim shall consist of not less than thirty two members. Therefore Sikkim has been provided exemption from the provisions mentioned in Article 170 (Legislative Assembly of each State shall consist of not more than five hundred and not less than sixty members) of the Constitution.

fields.question: Consider the following statements: 1. The Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha are not the members of that House. 2. While the nominated members of the two Houses of the Parliament have no voting right in the Presidential election, they have the right to vote in the election of the Vice President. Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
fields.explanation: According to Article 89 (1) of the Constitution, the Vice-President of India is ex officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha but he is not the member of Rajya Sabha. According to Article 89(2) of the Constitution, the Deputy Chairman is elected by Rajya Sabha itself from amongst its members. Hence statement 1 is incorrect. The electoral college for election of President consist of only elected members of Parliament and state legislative assembly and for vice president it consist of the members of Parliament.

fields.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct?
fields.option1: Only the Rajya Sabha and not Lok Sabha can have nominated members.
fields.option2: There is a Constitutional provision for nominating two members belonging to the Anglo-Indian Community to the Rajya Sabha.
fields.option3: There is no Constitutional bar for nominated members to be appointed as Union Ministers.
fields.option4: A nominated member can vote both in Presidential and Vice-Presidential elections.
fields.explanation: At the time when the question was asked, two members from the Anglo-Indian community were nominated by the President to the Lok Sabha, making statement 1 incorrect. The Constitution provides for 12 nominated members to the Rajya Sabha, not specifically for the Anglo-Indian community, thus statement 2 is incorrect. While there is no Constitutional bar for nominated members to become Union Ministers, this provision has not been implemented to date, so statement 3 is correct. Nominated members can vote only in the election of the Vice President, not the President, making statement 4 incorrect.

fields.question: Which one of the following motions can the Council of Ministers in India move?
fields.explanation: A Confidence Motion is moved by the Council of Ministers to demonstrate majority support in the House.

fields.question: Which of the following motions is related to the Union Budget?
fields.explanation: During the budget process, Cut Motions are moved by Members of the Lok Sabha to oppose or reduce specific demands in the budget. These include Policy Cut Motion, Economy Cut Motion, and Token Cut Motion.

fields.question: What is the primary objective of a 'Cut Motion'?
fields.option1: To put a check on the policies of the Government
fields.option2: To stop the functioning of the ruling party
fields.option3: To move a proposal to reduce expenditure in the Budget proposal
fields.option4: To reject the complete financial dealings of the Government
fields.explanation: Cut Motions aim to propose a reduction in the proposed expenditure in the Budget.

fields.question: What is correct about a starred question?
fields.explanation: A Starred Question requires an oral answer in the house and allows for supplementary questions based on the answer given.

fields.question: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched?
fields.option1: A starred Question to which a member desires an Oral Answer
fields.option2: An Unstarred Question - Supplementary question can be asked subsequently
fields.option3: A Short Notice question - Supplementary questions can be asked subsequently
fields.option4: A starred Question - Only 50 questions can be listed for oral answer a day
fields.explanation: A Short Notice Question is answered orally and allows for supplementary questions. An Unstarred Question is answered in writing and does not allow for supplementary questions.

fields.question: Which of the following expressions is appropriate regarding the message to call a joint sitting of both houses under Article 108 of the Constitution of India?
fields.explanation: The President's intention is what prompts the message to convene a joint sitting of both houses under Article 108 of the Constitution.

fields.question: Joint sitting of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha can take place to resolve deadlock over
fields.explanation: Joint sittings are called primarily to resolve deadlocks over ordinary legislation between the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha.

fields.question: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the Council of States (Rajya Sabha).
fields.option1: Dr. S. Radhakrishnan is the only Chairman of Rajya Sabha for two consecutive terms.
fields.option2: For the first constitutional amendment, ratification of the Rajya Sabha was not taken.
fields.option3: Currently, eight members are elected to Rajya Sabha from the Union Territories.
fields.option4: There have been three occasions when joint sittings of Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha were held.
fields.explanation: Dr. S. Radhakrishnan was Vice-President, not Chairman of Rajya Sabha, and served for two terms. The Rajya Sabha did not exist during the first constitutional amendment. Currently, four members are elected to Rajya Sabha from Union Territories.

fields.question: Consider the following statements about the Rajya Sabha of the Indian Parliament : (i) The Rajya Sabha has no power either to reject or to amend a Money Bill. (ii) The Rajya Sabha cannot vote the Demands of Grants. (iii) The Rajya Sabha cannot discuss the Annual Financial Statement. (iv) If any question arises regarding whether a Bill is Money Bill or not, the decision of the Chairperson shall not be final. Select the correct statements using the codes given below.
fields.explanation: The Rajya Sabha has no power either to reject or to amend a Money Bill (statement (i) is correct). The Rajya Sabha cannot vote the Demands of Grants (statement (ii) is correct). The Rajya Sabha can discuss the Annual Financial Statement (statement (iii) is incorrect). If any question arises regarding whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not, the decision of the Chairperson of the Lok Sabha is final (statement (iv) is correct).

fields.question: Out of the following, which is not a power granted to Rajya Sabha?
fields.option1: Authorizing Parliament in the national interest to make a law on a matter in the State List
fields.option2: Authorizing State Assemblies in the national interest to make law on matters in the Union List
fields.option3: To return a Money Bill with recommendations
fields.option4: Authorizing Parliament in the national interest to make a law for creation of an All India Service
fields.answer: Authorizing State Assemblies in the national interest to make law on matters in the Union List
fields.explanation: Rajya Sabha can authorize Parliament to make laws on State List subjects (statement (a) is correct). Rajya Sabha can return a Money Bill with recommendations (statement (c) is correct). Rajya Sabha can authorize Parliament to create an All India Service (statement (d) is correct). Rajya Sabha cannot authorize State Assemblies to make laws on Union List matters (statement (b) is incorrect).

fields.question: Who among the following is the first woman Speaker in Lok Sabha?
fields.explanation: Smt. Meira Kumar was the first woman Speaker of Lok Sabha. She served as the Speaker from 2009 to 2014.

fields.question: Which of the following (State- Number of Members in Lok Sabha) is not correctly matched?
fields.explanation: The correct match is as follows: Gujarat - 26, Haryana - 10, Himachal Pradesh - 4, Jharkhand - 14. Hence, the pair (d) is incorrectly matched.

fields.question: Consider the following statements. (i) The Lok Sabha Elections of 1989 marked the end of, what Political Scientists have called, the ‘Congress System’. (ii) Indian National Congress emerged as the single largest party in the 1989 Lok Sabha Elections.
fields.explanation: The Lok Sabha Elections of 1989 did mark the end of the 'Congress System' (statement (i) is correct). Indian National Congress emerged as the single largest party in the 1989 Lok Sabha Elections (statement (ii) is also correct).

fields.question: Money Bill can be presented
fields.option4: In joint meeting of both the Houses
fields.explanation: Money Bill can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha according to Article 110 of the Constitution of India.

fields.question: Which one of the following is authorized to prorogue the session of the House of the People?
fields.explanation: According to Article 85(2) of the Constitution, the President may prorogue either House of Parliament.

fields.question: Which of the following statements are correct in respect of Public Accounts Committee? (A) It comprises of 10 members of Lok Sabha and 7 members of Rajya Sabha. (B) A member of the opposition acts as its Chairman. (C) It examines the accounts of the Government corporations, autonomous and semi-autonomous bodies. (D) The Committee has the power to hear officials or take evidence connected with accounts under examination.
fields.explanation: The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) comprises 15 members from Lok Sabha and 7 members from Rajya Sabha (statement (A) is incorrect). A member of the opposition typically acts as the Chairman of PAC (statement (B) is correct). PAC examines the accounts of Government corporations, autonomous and semi-autonomous bodies (statement (C) is correct). PAC has the power to hear officials or take evidence connected with accounts under examination (statement (D) is correct).

fields.question: Public Accounts Committee has the following members, (Give the correct answer)-
fields.explanation: The correct composition of the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) is 15 members from Lok Sabha and 7 members from Rajya Sabha, making a total of 22 members.

fields.question: In the union government, the Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the:
fields.explanation: The Council of Ministers in the Union Government is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.

fields.question: Which of the following statements is correct about the Prime Minister of India?
fields.option1: Prime Minister is the nominal head of the Council of Ministers
fields.option2: He is not responsible to the Parliament
fields.option3: He cannot dismiss any of his ministers
fields.option4: Prime Minister is the real head of the Council of Ministers
fields.answer: Prime Minister is the real head of the Council of Ministers
fields.explanation: The Prime Minister of India is the real head of the Council of Ministers and is responsible to the Parliament.

fields.question: Who was the Chief Justice of India when public interest litigation (PIL) was introduced to the Indian Judicial System?
fields.explanation: Public Interest Litigation (PIL) was introduced to the Indian Judicial System during the tenure of Chief Justice P.N. Bhagwati.

fields.question: Which of the following statements are regarding Public Interest Litigation?
fields.option1: The person who is filing the petition must be the affected person/victim in the litigation.
fields.option2: The petition is accepted by the court only if there is interest of the affected person/victim involved.
fields.explanation: In Public Interest Litigation (PIL), the petitioner does not necessarily have to be the affected person/victim. The court may accept a petition if it involves public interest, even if the petitioner is not directly affected.
